case_name: Mohammad Naim v. Hon'ble Chief Justice and his companion judges of the Allahabad High Court

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 81 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 81 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 23, 1961 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Misc. Case No. 348/1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 23, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Criminal Misc. Case No. 348/1961.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge of Hardoi tried Zafar Ali Khan and three others on charges under ss. 452 and 307 read with s. 34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions judge of Hardoi in the State of Uttar Pradesh tried Zafar Ali Khan and three other persons on charges under ss. 452 and 307 read with s. 34, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: First information report lodged at Shahabad police station at about 3.30 A.M. by Farasat Ali Khan on the night between 7th and 8th November 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The case against the aforesaid accused persons started on a first information report lodged at a police station called Shahabad, purporting to have been so lodged at about 3.30 A. M. by one Farasat Ali Khan on the night between the 7th and 8th November, 1958.

facts.text: Case investigated by Mohammad Naim, Station Officer of Shahabad police station.

anchor.surface_text: The case was investigated by one Mohammad Naim who was then the Station Officer of Shahabad police station.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge convicted the accused persons but found FIR more probable at 7 or 8 A.M. rather than 3.30 A.M.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions judge companyvicted the accused persons though he found, on the evidence given in the case, that it was more probable that the first information was lodged at the police station at about 7 or 8 A.m. rather than at 3.30 A. M.

facts.text: Appeal to Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench heard by Mulla J. who acquitted the accused.

anchor.surface_text: From the companyviction and sentences passed by the Additional Sessions judge there was an appeal to the High Court at Allahabad  Lucknow Bench . This appeal was heard by Mulla J. He found that Mohammad Naim had dressed up a totally unbelievable case

facts.text: Mulla J. found Mohammad Naim fabricated FIR time, directed notice under s.195 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Learned judge allowed the appeal and set aside the companyviction and sentences of the four appellants before him. The learned judge further observed in his judgment There is ample evidence to prove that the first information report in this case was number lodged at 3.30 A. M.

facts.text: Mohammad Naim given notice in Cr. Misc. Case No. 87/1961, apologized, apology accepted hesitatingly.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the direction given by the learned Judge, Mohammad Naim was given a numberice to show cause why a companyplaint for an offence under s. 195 Indian Penal Code should number be made against him for fabricating the first information report in respect of the time at which it was said to have been lodged.

facts.text: Mulla J. made observations criticizing the police force in his order accepting apology.

anchor.surface_text: We may number quote those observations - I issued the numberice because I want to clean the public administration as for as possible but an individuals efforts cannot go very far. If I had felt that with my lone efforts I companyld have cleaned this augean stable, which is the police force

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh applied under s.561A CrPC to expunge specific observations grouped as a, b, c.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh felt aggrieved by some of the aforesaid observations and made an application under s. 561- A Code of Criminal Procedure for expunging them. The observations in respect of which the State of Uttar Pradesh felt aggrieved were grouped under heads  a ,  b  and  c  in paragraph 4 of the petition

facts.text: Mulla J. dismissed the application holding State had no locus standi and observations based on personal knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. justice Mulla heard the application and came to the following main companyclusions - That the State of Uttar Pradesh was number an aggrieved party and had numberlocus standi to make an application under s. 561-A Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of the observations made.

facts.text: State sought certificate under Art. 134(1)(c), denied, then special leave granted by SC on April 12, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The State then moved the High Court for a certificate of fitness under Art. 134 1   c  of the Constitution of India and being unsuccessful there, asked for special leave of this companyrt under Art. 136 of the Constitution. This companyrt granted special leave on April 12, 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 15, 1963 by K. DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 15. The judgment of the companyrt was delivered by K. DAS J.-This is an appeal by special leave, and it Presents some unusual features.

facts.text: Supreme Court held State of UP had locus standi to apply under s.561A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, companye to the companyclusion that the finding of the learned judge that the State Government has numberlocus standi to make the appli- cation under s. 561-A Cr. P.C. is erroneous in law.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court has inherent power under s.561A to expunge remarks in exceptional cases.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the view taken in the High Courts other than the High Court of Bombay is companyrect and the High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower companyrt

facts.text: Supreme Court found the case exceptional and directed expunging of remarks a, b, c.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we have companye to the companyclusion, a companyclusion which justice demands, that the present case is one of those exceptional cases where the inherent jurisdiction of the companyrt should have been exercised and the remarks earlier referred to as  a ,  b  and  c  should have been expunged.

facts.text: Mulla J. clarified observations were for UP police, not whole country.

anchor.surface_text: The observations required only one clarification namely, that they were made in respect of the police force of Uttar Pradesh and number of the whole companyntry.

facts.text: FIR time of 3.30 A.M. was fictitious as per Mulla J. and trial court finding.

anchor.surface_text: This is also the finding of trial companyrt. The time numbered in the first information report is, therefore, a fictitious time and a fabrication has been made in the public records.

facts.text: Conduct of Mohammad Naim deserves severest condemnation as per Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Having said all this, we must add, lest we be misunderstood, that the companyduct of Mohammad Naim and officers like him deserves the severest companydemnation, and the learned judge rightly observed that such companyduct required very serious numberice

issues.text: whether the State of Uttar Pradesh had locus standi to make the application under s. 561-A Cr. P. C.

anchor.surface_text: The first point which falls for consideration is whether the State of Uttar Pradesh had locus standi to make the application under s. 561-A Cr. P. C. We may first read the section Nothing in this Code

anchor.surface_text: The second point for consideration is this, has the High Court inherent power to expunge remarks made by itself or by a lower court to prevent abuse of the process of any court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. There was at one time some conflict

anchor.surface_text: The main ground which the State of Uttar Pradesh urged in support of their petition was that the observations over the entire police force, bring the same into contempt, lower its prestige in the eyes of mankind, have a tendency to interfere with the administration of the country and injure the security of the State.

anchor.surface_text: We may first read the section Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent power of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse

arguments.claim: State has locus standi as exercises exec power through police under Art.154 and General Clauses Act

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 154 of the Constitution the executive power of the State is vested in the Governor and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him. The expression State Government has a meaning

arguments.claim: State is juristic person; CrPC recognizes state rights in ss.417,439 etc.

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, it is not disputed that the State is a juristic person. The Code of Criminal Procedure itself recognises in some of its provisions the rights of the State Government such as, the right to give sanction

arguments.claim: No anomaly in state seeking redress under 561A like under 417 or 439

anchor.surface_text: We see nothing anomalous in the State Government moving the court for redress when it feels aggrieved by remarks made against it, The State Government may make an application to the High Court under s. 561-A

arguments.claim: HC has inherent power to expunge remarks; follows other HCs over Bombay view

anchor.surface_text: We think that the view taken in the High Courts other than the High Court of Bombay is correct and the High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower court

arguments.claim: SC examples: expunged remarks in prior cases

arguments.claim: Present case exceptional: apply test - party not before court, no evidence on record, not necessary for decision
Judicial pronouncements must be judicial, sober, moderate, reserved
Remarks sweeping, not justified, unnecessary; based on personal knowledge improperly
Counsel satisfied if expunge or hold unwarranted; purpose to remove stigma

anchor.surface_text: In fairness to learned counsel for the appellants we may state here that he has submitted before us that the State Government will be satisfied if we either expunge the remarks or hold them to be wholly unwarranted

court_response_anchor.surface_text: likely to undermine the efficiency of the entire police force. We think that in his zeal and solicitude for the reform of the police force, the learn

holdings.text: The State Government has locus standi to make the application under s. 561-A Cr. P.C.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the finding of the learned judge that the State Government has no locus standi to make the appli- cation under s. 561-A Cr. P.C. is erroneous in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State exercises executive power through police department under Art.154; defined in General Clauses Act; juristic person with rights under CrPC ss.417,439 etc.; no anomaly in invoking s.561A.

holdings.text: The High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower court to prevent abuse of the process of the court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice; jurisdiction exceptional.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the view taken in the High Courts other than the High Court of Bombay is correct and the High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower court

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.561A preserves inherent powers; follows majority High Court view over Bombay; precedents like State of UP v. J.N. Bagga where SC expunged remarks.

holdings.text: The present case is exceptional warranting exercise of inherent jurisdiction under s.561A to expunge remarks a, b, c.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we have come to the conclusion, a conclusion which justice demands, that the present case is one of those exceptional cases where the inherent jurisdiction of the court should have been exercised and the remarks earlier referred to as a , b and c should have been expunged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies three-factor test: party (police force) not before court; no evidence on record justifying sweeping remarks; remarks unnecessary for decision; violate judicial restraint; personal knowledge insufficient.

holdings.text: In making disparaging remarks against persons or authorities, courts must consider: (a) if party before court with opportunity to defend; (b) evidence on record justifying remarks; (c) necessity for decision.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicially recognised principles of justice, fairplay, restraint; applied to facts.

holdings.text: Judicial pronouncements must be judicial in nature, and should not normally depart from sobriety, moderation and reserve.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Established principle to guide judicial opinions.

holdings.text: The remarks against the entire police force were not justified, unnecessary, based improperly on personal knowledge without record evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence; sweeping generalisations; separable from decision on Naim; defeat reform purpose.

holdings.text: Conduct of Mohammad Naim and officers like him deserves severest condemnation; requires serious notice.

anchor.surface_text: Having said all this, we must add, lest we be misunderstood, that the conduct of Mohammad Naim and officers like him deserves the severest condemnation, and the learned judge rightly observed that such conduct required very serious notice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement with lower court on specific misconduct despite expunging general remarks.

precedents.cited_proposition: section 561A confers no new powers on the High Court but safeguards existing inherent powers

anchor.surface_text: and Emperor v. Nazir Ahmad 2 , We shall presently deal with the question whether the High Court has inherent power to expunge the remarks made by it or by a lower court to prevent abuse of the process of any court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Assuming that the High Court has such power, the question now before us is, can the State Government invoke this inherent jurisdiction of the High Court?

precedents.cited_proposition: section 561A confers no new powers on the High Court but safeguards existing inherent powers

anchor.surface_text: lsee Emperor v. Ch. Mohd. Hassan 1 State v. Chhotay Lal 2 Lalit Kumar v. S. S. Bose 1 Lal Singh v. State A.I.R. 1943 Lah. 298. 2 1955 A.L.J. 240. A.I.R. 1957 All. 398. A.I.R. 1959 Punj. 211. Ram Sagar Singh v. Chandrika Singh 1 and In re Ramaswami The view taken in the Bombay High Court is that the High Court has no jurisdiction to expunge passages from the judgment of an inferior court which has not been brought before it in regular appeal or revision but an application under s. 561-A Cr. P. C. is maintainable and in a proper case the High Court has inherent jurisdiction, even though no appeal or revision is preferred to it, to correct judicially the observations made by pointing out that they were not justified, or were without foundation, or were wholly wrong or improper I see State v. Nilkanth Shripad Bhave 3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: High Court has inherent power to expunge remarks from a judgment to secure ends of justice

P. anchor.surface_text: Ram Sagar Singh v. Chandrika Singh 1 and In re Ramaswami The view taken in the Bombay High Court is that the High Court has no jurisdiction to expunge passages from the judgment of an inferior court which has not been brought before it in regular appeal or revision but an application under s. 561-A Cr. P. C. is maintainable and in a proper case the High Court has inherent jurisdiction, even though no appeal or revision is preferred to it, to correct judicially the observations made by pointing out that they were not justified, or were without foundation, or were wholly wrong or improper I see State v. Nilkanth Shripad Bhave 3 . In State of U. P. v. J. N. Bagga 4 , this court made an order expunging certain remarks made against the State Government by a learned Judge of the High Court of Allahabad. The order was made in an appeal brought to this court from the appellate judgment and order of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: I see State v. Nilkanth Shripad Bhave 3 . In State of U. P. v. J. N. Bagga 4 , this court made an order expunging certain remarks made against the State Government by a learned Judge of the High Court of Allahabad. The order was made in an appeal brought to this court from the appellate judgment and order of the Allahabad High Court. In State of U. P. v. Ibrar Hussain 5 , this court observed that it was not necessary to make certain remarks which the High Court made in its judgment. Here again the observation was made in an appeal from the judgment and order of the High Court. We think that the view taken in the High Courts other than the High Court of Bombay is correct and the High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower court if it be necessary to do so to prevent abuse of the process of the court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice the jurisdiction is however of an exceptional nature and has to be exercised in exceptional cases only.

precedents.cited_proposition: Bombay High Court view: no jurisdiction to expunge from inferior court judgment unless in appeal/revision, but can correct observations if not justified

precedents.citation: State of U. P. v. J. N. Bagga 4

anchor.surface_text: In State of U. P. v. J. N. Bagga 4 , this court made an order expunging certain remarks made against the State Government by a learned Judge of the High Court of Allahabad. The order was made in an appeal brought to this court from the appellate judgment and order of the Allahabad High Court. In State of U. P. v. Ibrar Hussain 5 , this court observed that it was not necessary to make certain remarks which the High Court made in its judgment. Here again the observation was made in an appeal from the judgment and order of the High Court. We think that the view taken in the High Courts other than the High Court of Bombay is correct and the High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower court if it be necessary to do so to prevent abuse of the process of the court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice the jurisdiction is however of an exceptional nature and has to be exercised in exceptional cases only.

precedents.case_name: State of U. P. v. J. N. Bagga
precedents.cited_proposition: Supreme Court expunged remarks made against State Government by High Court judge

precedents.citation: State of U. P. v. Ibrar Hussain 5

anchor.surface_text: In State of U. P. v. Ibrar Hussain 5 , this court observed that it was not necessary to make certain remarks which the High Court made in its judgment. Here again the observation was made in an appeal from the judgment and order of the High Court. We think that the view taken in the High Courts other than the High Court of Bombay is correct and the High Court can in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction expunge remarks made by it or by a lower court if it be necessary to do so to prevent abuse of the process of the court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice the jurisdiction is however of an exceptional nature and has to be exercised in exceptional cases only. In fairness to learned counsel for the appellants we may state here that he has submitted before us that the State Government will be satisfied if we either expunge the remarks or hold them to be wholly unwarranted on the facts of the case.

precedents.case_name: State of U. P. v. Ibrar Hussain
precedents.cited_proposition: Supreme Court observed that certain remarks by High Court were not necessary
